title: 2 Kings Chapter 20 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Kings chapter 20 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Kings Chapter 20 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Kings Chapter 20.

questions.question: Who came to Hezekiah when he was sick unto death?
questions.correctAnswer: Isaiah the son of Amoz
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 20:1 states that the prophet Isaiah the son of Amoz came to Hezekiah when he was sick unto death.

questions.question: What did the LORD tell Hezekiah to do because he was going to die?
questions.correctAnswer: Set thine house in order
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 20:1, the LORD told Hezekiah to set his house in order because he was going to die and not live.

questions.question: What did Hezekiah do when he turned his face to the wall?
questions.correctAnswer: Prayed unto the LORD
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 20:2 says Hezekiah turned his face to the wall and prayed unto the LORD.

questions.question: What reason did Hezekiah give in his prayer to the LORD?
options: He walked before God in truth and with a perfect heart
He gave offerings to the priests
questions.correctAnswer: He walked before God in truth and with a perfect heart
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 20:3, Hezekiah prayed asking God to remember how he walked before Him in truth and with a perfect heart.

questions.question: How many years did the LORD promise to add to Hezekiah's life?
questions.correctAnswer: Fifteen years
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 20:6 states that the LORD promised to add fifteen years to Hezekiah's life.

questions.question: What sign did Isaiah give Hezekiah to prove he would be healed?
options: The shadow on the dial of Ahaz moving backward ten degrees
questions.correctAnswer: The shadow on the dial of Ahaz moving backward ten degrees
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 20:11 describes how the shadow on the dial of Ahaz moved backward ten degrees as a sign from the LORD.

questions.question: What was laid on Hezekiah's boil to help him recover?
questions.correctAnswer: A lump of figs
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 20:7 says Isaiah told them to take a lump of figs and lay it on the boil, after which Hezekiah recovered.

questions.question: Who sent letters and a present to Hezekiah after hearing he was sick?
questions.correctAnswer: Berodachbaladan, king of Babylon
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 20:12 states that Berodachbaladan, son of Baladan, king of Babylon, sent letters and a present to Hezekiah.

questions.question: What did Hezekiah show to the men from Babylon?
options: All his treasures and precious things
questions.correctAnswer: All his treasures and precious things
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 20:13 tells that Hezekiah showed the men from Babylon all the silver, gold, spices, ointment, armour, and treasures in his house.

questions.question: What warning did Isaiah give Hezekiah about the treasures and his descendants?
options: They will be carried into Babylon, and his sons taken as eunuchs
They will be destroyed by Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: They will be carried into Babylon, and his sons taken as eunuchs
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 20:17-18 warns that all treasures will be taken to Babylon and Hezekiah's sons will be taken and made eunuchs in Babylon.

questions.question: True or False: Hezekiah was angry with Isaiah for delivering the LORD's warning.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 20:19 shows Hezekiah responded that the word of the LORD was good because there was peace and truth in his days.

questions.question: True or False: Hezekiah built a pool and a conduit to bring water into the city.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 20:20 records that Hezekiah made a pool and conduit to bring water into the city.

questions.question: True or False: Hezekiah's son Manasseh did not become king after Hezekiah's death.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 20:21 states that Hezekiah slept with his fathers and Manasseh his son reigned in his stead.

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'I beseech thee, O LORD, remember now how I have walked before thee in ______ and with a perfect heart.'
questions.correctAnswer: truth
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 20:3 shows Hezekiah prayed asking God to remember how he walked before Him in truth and with a perfect heart.

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'I have heard thy prayer, I have seen thy ______: behold, I will heal thee.'
questions.correctAnswer: tears
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 20:5 states that the LORD heard Hezekiah's prayer and saw his tears, promising to heal him.

medium.title: 2 Kings Chapter 20 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Kings Chapter 20 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on 2 Kings 20, what biblical truth would you share about prayer and God's response?
options: God hears our prayers and can extend our lives when we sincerely seek Him
God ignores our prayers if we are in trouble
Prayer has no effect on our circumstances
We should only pray when we are healthy
questions.correctAnswer: God hears our prayers and can extend our lives when we sincerely seek Him
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 20:2-6 shows Hezekiah praying earnestly to God, who responds by healing him and adding fifteen years to his life, demonstrating that God listens and acts on sincere prayer.

questions.question: How does 2 Kings 20 teach about humility and dependence on God when facing life challenges?
options: Hezekiah humbled himself and prayed earnestly before God
Hezekiah relied solely on his own strength
Hezekiah tried to negotiate with Assyria himself
questions.correctAnswer: Hezekiah humbled himself and prayed earnestly before God
questions.explanation: Hezekiah turned his face to the wall and prayed with humility and sincerity (2 Kings 20:2-3), showing his dependence on God for healing and deliverance (2 Kings 20:5-6).

questions.question: What does the sign of the shadow going backward teach us about God's power and faithfulness?
options: God can perform miraculous signs to confirm His promises
God only works through human effort
The shadow sign was a coincidence, not a miracle
questions.correctAnswer: God can perform miraculous signs to confirm His promises
questions.explanation: Isaiah prayed and God caused the shadow on the sundial to go backward ten degrees, confirming His promise to heal Hezekiah (2 Kings 20:9-11). This demonstrates God's sovereign power and faithfulness.

questions.question: Based on 2 Kings 20, how should a believer respond to God’s promises even when facing difficult circumstances?
options: Respond with faith and ask for confirmation if needed
Doubt and refuse to believe God
Ignore God's promises and rely on luck
questions.correctAnswer: Respond with faith and ask for confirmation if needed
questions.explanation: Hezekiah asked for a sign to confirm God's promise (2 Kings 20:8-10), showing that it is appropriate to seek assurance from God while maintaining faith.

questions.question: What lesson about stewardship and integrity can be drawn from Hezekiah showing all his treasures to Babylonian envoys?
options: Be cautious in sharing personal or spiritual resources with outsiders
Always share everything with strangers without thought
questions.correctAnswer: Be cautious in sharing personal or spiritual resources with outsiders
questions.explanation: Hezekiah showed all his treasures to the envoys (2 Kings 20:13), which Isaiah later warned could lead to loss (2 Kings 20:16-18). This teaches prudence and wisdom in stewardship and sharing.

questions.question: How does Hezekiah's response to Isaiah’s prophecy about Babylon illustrate contentment and trust in God’s plan?
options: He accepted the word of the LORD with peace and trust
He rebelled and refused to accept God's word
He tried to bribe the Babylonians
questions.correctAnswer: He accepted the word of the LORD with peace and trust
questions.explanation: Hezekiah said, 'Good is the word of the LORD which thou hast spoken' (2 Kings 20:19), showing humility and trust even in difficult prophecy.

questions.question: What does this passage teach about the importance of personal devotion and prayer in spiritual discipline?
options: Personal heartfelt prayer can bring God’s attention and intervention
Prayers should be public and showy to impress others
Prayer is unnecessary when facing trials
questions.correctAnswer: Personal heartfelt prayer can bring God’s attention and intervention
questions.explanation: Hezekiah’s private prayer (2 Kings 20:2-3) was sincere and moved God to heal him (2 Kings 20:5-6), illustrating the power of personal devotion.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Kings 20, God extended Hezekiah's life because of his sincere prayer and faith.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: God heard Hezekiah’s prayer and added fifteen years to his life as a response to his faith and sincere prayer (2 Kings 20:5-6).

questions.question: True or False: Hezekiah’s sharing of his treasures with Babylonian envoys was praised by Isaiah as an example of wise stewardship.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah warned Hezekiah that sharing all his treasures would lead to future loss and exile (2 Kings 20:16-18), indicating it was not wise stewardship.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Hezekiah prayed to the LORD, asking Him to remember how he had walked before Him in ______ and with a perfect heart.
questions.correctAnswer: truth
questions.explanation: Hezekiah prayed asking God to remember how he had walked before Him in truth and with a perfect heart (2 Kings 20:3), emphasizing integrity and faithfulness.

questions.question: How does this passage encourage believers to deal with fear and uncertainty?
options: Bring fears to God in prayer and trust His promises
Hide fears and pretend all is well
questions.correctAnswer: Bring fears to God in prayer and trust His promises
questions.explanation: Hezekiah turned to God in prayer when facing death (2 Kings 20:2-3) and trusted God’s promise for healing (2 Kings 20:5-6), showing how to handle fear.

questions.question: What spiritual principle can be learned from God defending Jerusalem for His own sake and for David's sake?
options: God is faithful to His covenant promises and protects His people
God only protects when people are perfect
God’s protection is based on human strength
questions.correctAnswer: God is faithful to His covenant promises and protects His people
questions.explanation: God promised to defend Jerusalem for His own sake and for David's sake (2 Kings 20:6), showing His covenant faithfulness and protection.

questions.question: How does Hezekiah’s example teach us about trust and obedience in leadership and family life?
options: Trust God’s guidance and obey His Word for the good of the family and kingdom
Rely on human power alone to lead
Ignore God’s prophets when making decisions
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God’s guidance and obey His Word for the good of the family and kingdom
questions.explanation: Hezekiah followed the prophet Isaiah's message and trusted God’s word (2 Kings 20:16-19), demonstrating obedience and trust important for leadership and family.

questions.question: What does the healing with the lump of figs teach us about God's use of natural means in His miraculous works?
options: God can use simple natural remedies as instruments of healing
Healing only comes through elaborate rituals
God never uses natural elements for healing
Figs were the true source of healing, not God
questions.correctAnswer: God can use simple natural remedies as instruments of healing
questions.explanation: Isaiah instructed to use a lump of figs on the boil, and Hezekiah recovered (2 Kings 20:7), showing God’s power can work through natural means.

questions.question: What does Hezekiah’s instruction to set his house in order teach about preparing for the end of life?
options: It is wise to prepare spiritually and practically when facing death
Ignore the reality of death and live carelessly
Only focus on material possessions at the end
questions.correctAnswer: It is wise to prepare spiritually and practically when facing death
questions.explanation: Isaiah told Hezekiah to set his house in order because he was to die (2 Kings 20:1), which implies the importance of preparation for death in faith and life.

hard.title: 2 Kings Chapter 20 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Kings Chapter 20.

questions.question: What was the initial message Isaiah delivered to King Hezekiah about his health?
options: He was going to recover fully
He would die and should set his house in order
questions.correctAnswer: He would die and should set his house in order
questions.explanation: Isaiah told Hezekiah to set his house in order because he would die and not live, as noted in 2 Kings 20:1.

questions.question: How did Hezekiah respond immediately after hearing Isaiah's prophecy of his impending death?
options: He turned his face to the wall and prayed
questions.correctAnswer: He turned his face to the wall and prayed
questions.explanation: Hezekiah turned his face to the wall and prayed to the LORD, demonstrating his humility and earnest petition, as recorded in 2 Kings 20:2.

questions.question: Which phrase in Hezekiah's prayer indicates his awareness of his faithful walk before God?
options: "I have walked before thee in truth and with a perfect heart"
"I have built altars to other gods"
"I have sought the help of Assyria"
questions.correctAnswer: "I have walked before thee in truth and with a perfect heart"
questions.explanation: Hezekiah prays, asking God to remember how he has walked before Him in truth and with a perfect heart, showing his faithfulness, as in 2 Kings 20:3.

questions.question: What was God's response to Hezekiah's prayer and tears according to Isaiah's message?
options: God heard his prayer and would heal him
questions.correctAnswer: God heard his prayer and would heal him
questions.explanation: God told Isaiah to inform Hezekiah that He had heard his prayer, seen his tears, and would heal him (2 Kings 20:5).

questions.question: How many years did God promise to add to Hezekiah's life?
questions.correctAnswer: Fifteen years
questions.explanation: God promised to add fifteen years to Hezekiah’s life as part of His deliverance plan (2 Kings 20:6).

questions.question: The healing of Hezekiah involved which unusual remedy?
options: Applying oil from a sacred lamp
Laying a lump of figs on the boil
Drinking water from the Jordan River
questions.correctAnswer: Laying a lump of figs on the boil
questions.explanation: Isaiah instructed that a lump of figs be laid on Hezekiah’s boil, which led to his recovery (2 Kings 20:7).

questions.question: What sign did Hezekiah request to confirm God's promise of healing?
options: The shadow on the dial of Ahaz moving backward
A dove landing on the temple
questions.correctAnswer: The shadow on the dial of Ahaz moving backward
questions.explanation: Hezekiah asked whether the shadow should go forward or backward ten degrees; God caused it to move backward as a sign (2 Kings 20:9-11).

questions.question: Who sent letters and a present to Hezekiah upon hearing of his illness?
questions.correctAnswer: Berodachbaladan, king of Babylon
questions.explanation: Berodachbaladan, son of Baladan, king of Babylon, sent letters and a present to Hezekiah after hearing of his sickness (2 Kings 20:12).

questions.question: How did Hezekiah respond to the envoys from Babylon?
options: He showed them all his treasures
He gave them a secret message
questions.correctAnswer: He showed them all his treasures
questions.explanation: Hezekiah showed the Babylonian envoys all his precious things and treasures in his house and kingdom (2 Kings 20:13).

questions.question: What was Isaiah’s prophetic warning to Hezekiah about showing the Babylonian envoys his treasures?
options: His treasures and descendants would be taken to Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: His treasures and descendants would be taken to Babylon
questions.explanation: Isaiah warned that all the treasures and some of Hezekiah’s descendants would be carried off to Babylon (2 Kings 20:17-18).

questions.question: What was Hezekiah’s reaction to Isaiah’s prophecy of exile and captivity?
options: He accepted it as good if peace and truth were in his days
He sought to hide the prophecy
questions.correctAnswer: He accepted it as good if peace and truth were in his days
questions.explanation: Hezekiah responded that the word of the LORD was good if peace and truth were in his days, showing a submissive attitude (2 Kings 20:19).

questions.question: Besides his illness and healing, what significant infrastructure project did Hezekiah undertake according to this chapter?
options: Making a pool and a conduit to bring water into the city
questions.correctAnswer: Making a pool and a conduit to bring water into the city
questions.explanation: Hezekiah made a pool, a conduit, and brought water into the city as recorded in the chronicles mentioned in 2 Kings 20:20.

questions.question: What is the significance of the shadow going backward on the dial of Ahaz in relation to ancient Near Eastern culture?
options: It symbolized the reversal of time and divine intervention
It was a common astronomical phenomenon
It represented the king’s power over nature
It was a sign of the Babylonian calendar
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolized the reversal of time and divine intervention
questions.explanation: The shadow moving backward was a miraculous sign reversing natural order symbolizing God’s power to intervene, significant in the context of ancient Near Eastern beliefs about time and divine authority (2 Kings 20:9-11).

questions.question: True or False: The chapter 2 Kings 20 shows Hezekiah’s faith and repentance as the reason for his healing and prolonged life.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hezekiah’s prayer and his walk before God in truth and purity are explicitly connected to God’s mercy and healing in this chapter (2 Kings 20:3-6).

questions.question: How does Hezekiah’s interaction with Babylon foreshadow future events in Israel’s history?
options: It predicts an alliance between Judah and Babylon
It foreshadows Babylonian exile and captivity
It marks the beginning of Babylonian decline
It shows Babylonian submission to Judah
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows Babylonian exile and captivity
questions.explanation: The prophecy that treasures and descendants would be taken to Babylon anticipates the Babylonian exile of Judah, a major event in biblical history (2 Kings 20:17-18).

theological.title: 2 Kings Chapter 20 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Kings Chapter 20 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the initial message from the LORD to Hezekiah through Isaiah regarding his illness?
options: Set thine house in order; for thou shalt die, and not live
You will recover and strengthen your kingdom
You will defeat the king of Assyria
Your prayer has been heard and you will live
questions.correctAnswer: Set thine house in order; for thou shalt die, and not live
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 20:1, the prophet Isaiah tells Hezekiah that he must set his house in order because he will die. This reflects God's sovereign judgment over life and death (Psalm 90:10; James 4:14).

questions.question: How did Hezekiah respond when he was told he would die?
options: He turned his face to the wall and prayed
He sent gifts to the king of Assyria
He built a pool for water
questions.correctAnswer: He turned his face to the wall and prayed
questions.explanation: According to 2 Kings 20:2, Hezekiah turned his face to the wall and prayed to the LORD, showing his humility and dependence on God in a crisis, consistent with scriptural calls to prayer in distress (Psalm 34:17; Daniel 6:10).

questions.question: What reason did Hezekiah give to God in his prayer for healing?
options: He had walked before God in truth with a perfect heart and done good
He had built the city walls
He had given offerings to the temple
questions.correctAnswer: He had walked before God in truth with a perfect heart and done good
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 20:3, Hezekiah appeals to his faithfulness and righteousness, highlighting the biblical principle that God honors sincere obedience and a pure heart (Psalm 15:2; 1 Samuel 2:35).

questions.question: What was God's promise to Hezekiah after hearing his prayer and seeing his tears?
options: He would heal him and add fifteen years to his life
He would grant him a son
He would make him king over all nations
questions.correctAnswer: He would heal him and add fifteen years to his life
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 20:5-6 shows God’s sovereign grace extending life to Hezekiah, a demonstration of divine mercy and power over death (Psalm 103:3; Isaiah 38:5). This foreshadows Christ’s authority over life and death (John 11:25).

questions.question: What sign did Isaiah give Hezekiah to confirm God's promise of healing?
options: The shadow on the dial of Ahaz would move backward ten degrees
The sun would darken at noon
A fig tree would bear fruit immediately
The city walls would be rebuilt overnight
questions.correctAnswer: The shadow on the dial of Ahaz would move backward ten degrees
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 20:9-11, God miraculously causes the shadow to retreat, confirming His sovereign control over nature and His faithfulness to His word (Exodus 14:21-22; Psalm 19:1). This miracle points to God’s power over creation.

questions.question: What was laid on Hezekiah's boil as part of his healing?
questions.correctAnswer: A lump of figs
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 20:7 describes the use of a lump of figs on Hezekiah’s boil, demonstrating God's use of natural means for healing, consistent with biblical principles of God’s provision through creation (Jeremiah 8:22; Luke 10:34).

questions.question: Who sent letters and a present to Hezekiah after hearing of his illness?
questions.correctAnswer: Berodachbaladan, king of Babylon
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 20:12 records that Berodachbaladan, king of Babylon, sent letters and gifts, reflecting the political intrigue and international awareness of Judah's affairs, which God sovereignly allows (Daniel 2:37-38; Isaiah 39:1).

questions.question: What did Hezekiah show to the Babylonian envoys?
options: All his treasures, including silver, gold, spices, ointment, armor, and valuables
questions.correctAnswer: All his treasures, including silver, gold, spices, ointment, armor, and valuables
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 20:13 states Hezekiah showed all his treasures, illustrating human pride and the danger of revealing God's blessings to ungodly nations (Proverbs 25:2; Isaiah 39:2). This foreshadows the Babylonian exile (Jeremiah 52:17-23).

questions.question: What was Isaiah's prophecy regarding the treasures and descendants of Hezekiah?
options: They would be carried into Babylon and his sons taken as eunuchs
They would be hidden and preserved
They would be given as gifts to the king of Assyria
They would multiply and prosper in Judah
questions.correctAnswer: They would be carried into Babylon and his sons taken as eunuchs
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 20:17-18, Isaiah foretells the Babylonian exile and captivity of Judah’s descendants, highlighting God's judgment and the consequences of political alliances, consistent with Jeremiah 29:10 and Daniel 1:3-4.

questions.question: How did Hezekiah respond to Isaiah's prophecy about the future captivity?
options: He said, 'Good is the word of the LORD which thou hast spoken'
He sought an alliance with Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: He said, 'Good is the word of the LORD which thou hast spoken'
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 20:19 reveals Hezekiah’s acceptance, showing trust in God's sovereignty and peace even amid judgment, echoing Job's submission (Job 1:21) and Paul’s teaching on God's purposes (Romans 8:28).

questions.question: What did God say He would do for Jerusalem and for His servant David's sake?
options: Deliver and defend the city from the king of Assyria
Make the city wealthy and prosperous
Give the city to the Babylonians
Destroy the city for its sins
questions.correctAnswer: Deliver and defend the city from the king of Assyria
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 20:6 states God’s promise to defend Jerusalem for His own name’s sake and David’s, showing God's faithfulness to His covenant (2 Samuel 7:16; Psalm 89:3-4; Isaiah 37:35).

questions.question: According to 2 Kings 20, what was Hezekiah's legacy recorded in the chronicles?
options: His acts, might, and the construction of a pool and conduit to bring water into the city
His establishment of new religious festivals
His laws given to the priests
questions.correctAnswer: His acts, might, and the construction of a pool and conduit to bring water into the city
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 20:20 records Hezekiah’s practical works, emphasizing the biblical value of godly leadership in stewardship and provision (Nehemiah 2:17-18; Ecclesiastes 7:12).

questions.question: What does Hezekiah's healing and extended life reveal about the nature of God?
options: God is merciful, sovereign over life and death, and responsive to prayer
God is indifferent to human suffering
God punishes all sinners without exception
questions.correctAnswer: God is merciful, sovereign over life and death, and responsive to prayer
questions.explanation: The narrative (2 Kings 20:1-6) shows God’s mercy and sovereignty, consistent with Job 33:23-26, Psalm 30:2, James 5:15, and John 10:17-18, affirming His power over death and His compassionate nature.

questions.question: What theological theme is illustrated by God adding fifteen years to Hezekiah's life?
options: God’s grace extends life beyond human merit
questions.correctAnswer: God’s grace extends life beyond human merit
questions.explanation: God’s granting of extra years (2 Kings 20:6) exemplifies grace, not earned by works but given by divine mercy (Ephesians 2:8-9; Romans 5:20; Psalm 23:6; Isaiah 38:5).

questions.question: What does the story of the shadow moving backward signify about God's control over creation?
options: God has authority over natural laws and confirms His word through miracles
The shadow moving is a natural event with no significance
God only works miracles in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: God has authority over natural laws and confirms His word through miracles
questions.explanation: The miraculous reversal of the shadow (2 Kings 20:11) demonstrates God’s power over nature, affirming His sovereignty as seen in Exodus 14:21-22, Joshua 10:13, Psalm 104:5-9, and John 11:43-44.
